claims.claim: A Brighter Way was started by formerly incarcerated individuals aiming for a better approach to reentry support.
claims.quote: Our organization's called A Brighter Way, and it was started by three individuals who were formally incarcerated and they realized that there had to be a better way of doing things than they were doing at the time.

claims.claim: A Brighter Way evolved from a faith-based, SUD-focused model to a more inclusive navigation model.
claims.quote: And then they pulled back a little bit on that. They had a little bit of an s u d focus and they were in, in resource, rich Washtenaw County. But they weren't really able to tap into a lot of the resources.

claims.claim: A Brighter Way shifted from a mentoring to a navigation approach to avoid hierarchical implications.
claims.quote: Mentoring has this hierarchical intonation to it. And so what we're doing is, is we're helping to navigate systems that we've all previously navigated.

claims.claim: A Brighter Way's staff includes individuals who have served significant time in incarceration, emphasizing lived experience.
claims.quote: ...the shirt that I'm wearing that you see, the 27 on my shoulders. It says A Brighter Way. It's got my name on the back and it's got the number of years that I served. Everybody in the office has the same thing.

claims.claim: A Brighter Way offers highly individualized support services to formerly incarcerated individuals.
claims.quote: We do individualized wraparound services and I can't even explain fully what those are because until I meet the person, I can't decide what those things are.

claims.claim: The organization focuses on improving quality of life rather than solely aiming to reduce recidivism.
claims.quote: But our model is not a recidivism model. Our model is a quality of life model. Because recidivism doesn't have anything to do with the human quality of life is a very humane way of looking at this issue.
